translated: In the same way, for the proponents of non-God, such as the Buddhists, in pure consciousness continua and so on, due to the impossibility of the dominant, cooperative, and other causes and their qualities, and because of the acceptance of natural self-referential validity,

analyzed: samāḥ ca ṛcāḥ
translated: the arguments are equal.

analyzed: yadi api pūrva pratyayasya akāraṇa tvam iṣṭam
translated: Although the previous condition is accepted as the cause,

analyzed: tathā api tasya apavarga daśā sthasya guṇa doṣa ādi rūpa samasta saṃskāra pratyarthi tayā na tad janyasya guṇa hetu tā iti
translated: nevertheless, for one in the state of final liberation, due to being opposed to all impressions in the form of virtues, faults, and so on, the cause of virtue is not produced by that.

analyzed: yat ca prāmāṇyam paratas jñāyate  iti prayuktam
translated: And what is argued: Validity is known from another.

analyzed: tatra jñāna antareṇa jñāna antara svabhāva vedanā abhyupagamāt siddha sādhana tā
translated: There, because of the acceptance of the experience of the nature of one cognition by another cognition, the argument is established.

original: parata eveti vivakṣāyāmīdṛśaṃ jñānaṃ prameti lakṣaṇataḥ sarvapramāsaṅgrāhiṇi jñāne pārameśvare ca vijñāne tadasaṃbhavaḥ /
analyzed: paratas eva iti vivakṣāyām īdṛśam jñānam pramā iti lakṣaṇataḥ sarva pramā saṅgrāhiṇi jñāne pārameśvare ca vijñāne tad asaṃbhavaḥ
translated: If the intention is that it is only from another, then such knowledge is not possible in the knowledge of God, which includes all valid cognitions by the definition of valid cognition as knowledge that is non-deceptive.

original: na hi tābhyāṃ svapramātvaṃ na gṛhītam /
analyzed: na hi tābhyām sva pramā tvam na gṛhītam
translated: For they do not fail to apprehend their own validity.
Because it would lead to the absurd consequence of being a knower of some things that are not covered by the definition.

original: atonyatra parata eveti niyama iti cet /
analyzed: atas nyatra paratas eva iti niyamaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that therefore the rule is that it is only from another in other cases,

analyzed: tat api na
translated: that is also not so.

original: taddṛṣṭāntenaiva pratiprayoktuṃ śakyatvātvigītaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ svādhāreṇa jñāyate /
analyzed: tad dṛṣṭāntena eva pratiprayoktum śakya tvāt vigītam prāmāṇyam sva ādhāreṇa jñāyate
translated: Because it can be refuted by the same example. The validity that is accepted is known by its own substratum.

analyzed: prāmāṇya rūpa tvāt
translated: Because it is of the nature of validity.
Like the validity of the knowledge of God and so on.

original: kathaṃ tarhi idaṃ pramāṇamapramāṇaṃ veti saṃśayāvakāśaḥ /
analyzed: katham tarhi idam pramāṇam apramāṇam vā iti saṃśaya avakāśaḥ
translated: If it is argued that how then is there room for doubt as to whether this is valid knowledge or not,

analyzed: iti ced na viśeṣataḥ gṛhyamāṇeṣu api saṃśaya utpatti darśanāt
translated: that is not so. Because doubt is seen to arise even when things are apprehended in detail.

original: bhavati muhuḥ śuktikārajatamohādandhīkṛtadhiyaḥ kaladhautepi tathopalabhyamāne yathopalambhamidaṃ rajatameva vā pūrvavacchuktirajataṃ veti
analyzed: bhavati muhur śuktikā rajata mohāt andhīkṛta dhiyaḥ kaladhaute api tathā upalabhyamāne yathā upalambham idam rajatam eva vā pūrvavat śukti rajatam vā iti
translated: For one whose mind is repeatedly blinded by the delusion of silver in a shell, even when silver is perceived in a polished piece of silver, there arises the doubt as to whether it is silver as it is perceived, or whether it is the silver of the shell as before.

original: tathātrāpi gṛhyamāṇepi prāmāṇye kimidaṃ pramāṇameva sat pramāṇatayopalambhate /
analyzed: tathā atra api gṛhyamāṇe ipi prāmāṇye kim idam pramāṇam eva sat pramāṇa tayā upalambhate
translated: Similarly, even if validity is apprehended here, is this valid cognition apprehended as valid because it exists as a valid cognition?

analyzed: uta bādhāt pūrva bhrama vat apramāṇam sat
translated: Or, because of sublation, does it exist as an invalid cognition like a previous error?

analyzed: iti saṃśayaḥ yuktaḥ
translated: Thus doubt is appropriate.

analyzed: tathā api sandeha sahena kim svatas grahaṇena
translated: Even so, what is the use of grasping it with doubt?

analyzed: niścayaḥ tu para adhīnaḥ evā iti ced
translated: But certainty is dependent on others.

analyzed: kim asmad apekṣayā grahaṇam agrahaṇam vā niyantum śakyam
translated: Can grasping or non-grasping be controlled in relation to us?

analyzed: siddhaḥ hi grahaṇa prakāraḥ parīkṣakaiḥ anusaraṇīyaḥ
translated: The mode of grasping that is established should be followed by investigators.

analyzed: siddhiḥ eva svatas katham iti ced
translated: If it is asked how establishment is by itself,

original: itthamjñānaṃ svālambanaṃ prakāśayat svayamapi jñānāntaranirapekṣaṃ prakāśate /
analyzed: ittham jñānam sva ālambanam prakāśayat svayam api jñāna antara nirapekṣam prakāśate
translated: it is thus: knowledge, illuminating its own object, also illuminates itself independently of other knowledge.

analyzed: iti tāvat sarva vedānti saṃmatam
translated: Thus, this is accepted by all Vedāntins.

analyzed: a svayam prakāśa vādaḥ api sva grāhiṇā anuvyavasāyena prakāśamānaḥ vyavasāyaḥ tāvat asaṃśaya ātmā eva dṛśyate
translated: Even in the doctrine of non-self-illumination, the cognition that appears by the subsequent cognition apprehending itself is seen to be of the nature of certainty alone.

original: nyā / pa / śa / smṛtyaprāmāṇyavādepyapūrvārthagocaratayā smṛtivilakṣaṇaścāviparyayātmā cābādhātmā ca /
analyzed: smṛti aprāmāṇya vāda īpya pūrva artha gocara tayā smṛti vilakṣaṇaḥ ca aviparyaya ātmā ca ābādha ātmā ca
translated: Even in the doctrine of the invalidity of memory, it is different from memory in cognizing a new object, and it is of the nature of non-error because of non-sublation.

analyzed: vādha ādeḥ pūrvam tad prasaṅga abhāvāt
translated: Because before sublation and so on, there is no possibility of it.

analyzed: tatas ca yad viṣaya tayā ayam vyavasāyaḥ prathamam pratibhātaḥ
translated: And therefore, by virtue of which object this ascertainment appears first,

analyzed: tad viṣaya tayā eva paraspara parikṣodāt paścāt api
translated: by virtue of that very object, it is established later also by mutual examination.

original: ato yat tadviṣayatvalakṣaṇaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ paścāt tenaiva vyavasthāpyate /🔽tadādāveva gṛhītamiti svataḥ prāmāṇyagrahaḥ //
analyzed: atas yat tad viṣaya tva lakṣaṇam prāmāṇyam paścāt tena eva vyavasthāpyate  tad ādau eva gṛhītam iti svatas prāmāṇya grahaḥ
translated: Therefore, that validity which consists in being of the nature of that object is established later by that very [ascertainment].🔽Since it was apprehended at the beginning, the apprehension of validity is self-sufficient.

original: nyā / pa / śa / nanvevaṃ saṃśayatvādilakṣaṇamaprāmāṇyamapi svayaṃprakāśenānuvyavasāyena vā prathamamave grahītuṃ śakyam /
analyzed: nanu evam saṃśaya tva ādi lakṣaṇam aprāmāṇyam api svayam prakāśeṇa anuvyavasāyena vā grahītum śakyam
translated: Now, in this way, invalidity characterized by doubt, etc. can also be apprehended first by the self-luminous subsequent cognition.

analyzed: tathā api viparyaya tva lakṣaṇam na tathā
translated: However, invalidity characterized by error is not so.

analyzed: gṛhyamāṇa vaiparītyasya svena sva grāhiṇā vā prathamam agrahaṇāt
translated: Because the contradiction that is being apprehended is not apprehended first by itself or by what apprehends itself.

analyzed: tasmin aṃśe ca vaidikānām avivādāt
translated: And because there is no dispute among the Vedic scholars regarding that part [of the cognition].

analyzed: tatra imam aṃśam ādāya eva ca antataḥ pasvataḥ prāmāṇya samarthana pravṛtteḥ
translated: And because the attempt to establish self-sufficient validity is made only on the basis of that part [of the cognition].

analyzed: tatra doṣa abhāvāt eva ādau aprāmāṇya anutpatteḥ
translated: Because invalidity does not arise at the beginning due to the absence of defects.

analyzed: tatas eva ca aprāmāṇya pramiti asaṃbhavāt
translated: And because the apprehension of invalidity is not possible from that [absence of defects] itself.

original: svata eva ca prāmāṇyapramiterabādhācca ityucyate / iti //
analyzed: svatas eva ca prāmāṇya pramiteḥ abādhāt ca iti ucyate iti
translated: And because the apprehension of validity is not contradicted by itself. Thus it is said.

original: iti kavitārkikasiṃhasya sarvatantrasvatantrasya śrīmadveṅkaṭanāthasya vedāntācāryasya kṛtiṣu nyāyapariśuddhau śabdādhyāye prathamamāhnikam
analyzed: iti kavi tārkikasiṃhasya sarva tantra svatantrasya śrīmat veṅkaṭanāthasya vedānta ācāryasya kṛtiṣu nyāyapariśuddhau śabda adhyāye prathamam āhnikam
translated: Thus ends the first chapter in the Śabda (word and meaning) section of Nyāyapariśuddhi, composed by the illustrious Vedāntācārya Śrī Veṅkaṭanātha, the independent master of all scriptures, the lion among poets and logicians.
